meanings.definition: Treat with an apparent kindness that betrays a feeling of superiority.
meanings.sent1: She patronised her younger sister by offering to help with her homework but correcting every mistake.
meanings.sent2: The wealthy woman patronised the local charity event, looking down on the other attendees.
meanings.sent3: The cat patronised the dog by allowing it to play with its favorite toy, but always snatching it away at the last moment.
meanings.sent4: His smile patronised her, as if he thought she couldn't understand the complex topic.
meanings.sent5: The teacher patronised the student, speaking slowly and using simple words as if the student were a child.

meanings.definition: Frequent (a store, theater, restaurant, etc.) as a customer.
meanings.sent1: He patronised the local bakery every morning for his favorite pastries.
meanings.sent2: The couple patronised the new restaurant in town, enjoying the delicious food and friendly service.
meanings.sent3: She patronised the bookstore so often that the owner knew her by name and recommended new releases.
meanings.sent4: The old man patronised the same barber shop for decades, loyal to the skilled barber.
meanings.sent5: The family patronised the small theater in their neighborhood, attending every play and supporting local talent.

meanings.definition: Act as a patron and support financially.
meanings.sent1: The wealthy businessman patronised the arts by funding scholarships for young artists.
meanings.sent2: She patronised the local animal shelter, donating food and supplies regularly.
meanings.sent3: The company patronised the community center, sponsoring events and programs for the residents.
meanings.sent4: He patronised the museum, contributing to the preservation of historical artifacts.
meanings.sent5: The organization patronised the school, providing resources for educational programs and extracurricular activities.
